name: Palisado Cemetery
description: THE HEADSTONE OF EPHRAIM HUIT is inscribed with the year 1644. It is not the oldest grave or the first burial in the country, but it is the oldest surviving headstone in Connecticut and believed to be the oldest legible, dated headstone in the United States.

name: Vintage Radio & Communications Museum of CT
description: More than a century of radio history is told in these displays. Listen to pop music from throughout the 20th century on a variety of jukeboxes, put on a set of vintage headphones and tune into live radio broadcasts on a period crystal radio, and dial up friends and family using rotary phones and in phone booths. All that and more is ready to be experienced at this museum dedicated to educating the public about the history of electronic communications and the state’s contributions. Proceeding chronologically from the 1850s through the 1970s, the museum chronicles the rise of radio and evolution of communications through a collection of radios, typewriters and industrial equipment, phonographs, televisions, TV studio equipment, telephones, recording studio equipment, and even the first computers. Also explore the rivalries between communications pioneers Thomas Edison and Alexander Graham Bell and, later, Edison and George Westinghouse and Nikola Tesla, by trying out Edison’s early lightbulb designs and a miniature version of Tesla’s renowned coil.

name: Matianuck Natural Area Preserve
description: Sand dunes from a glacial lake are preserved in this woodland park.

name: State House Square
description: site of Isle of Safety : The former location of a platform that allowed passengers to safely wait for the trolley.

name: Connecticut's Old State House
description:
A wunderkammer hidden on the top floor of the Hartford statehouse. 
"The place where Connecticut’s democracy was born has seen more than its fair share of hard times. Nearly demolished at least twice in the 20th century, including in the 1970s when it almost faced the wrecking ball to make way for a parking lot, the National Historic Landmark built in 1796 closed last summer due to budget cuts. But the Old State House, which was Connecticut’s original seat of government from 1796 to 1878, is once again open to the public. Stroll through the chambers of the House of Representatives and the Senate, where the Amistad trial began and the 13th Amendment was ratified, and spy an original portrait of George Washington. Resist the urge to take a spin on Mark Twain’s bicycle. Things get a little wacky when you venture upstairs into the Museum of Natural and Other Curiosities, where the walls are lined with rare masks, animal heads and bizarre items such as a “unicorn’s horn” and a two-headed calf."

name: Ancient Burial Ground
description: The oldest place in Hartford is a cemetery with thousands of bodies stacked beneath the grass.

name: Horace Wells Statue
description: The tragic tale of the dentist who pioneered the use of anesthesia.

name: Statue of Rover
description:
A tribute to the truly loyal dog who waited outside a hospital for his owner to come back.
When facing the front entrance to the main Hartford Hospital go to the left side of the entrance. The statue is close to the wall near the windows.

name: Cathedral of Saint Joseph
description: This Connecticut chapel is a starkly modern, and surprisingly colorful, architectural rebel. "The original cathedral, with its classical twin Gothic spires, was destroyed by a New Year’s Eve fire in 1956. The church that replaced it — a 281-foot concrete and limestone edifice with straight lines and hard edges — would have been unrecognizable to those familiar with the original. But inside is where the beauty truly lies. Even for the non-religious, being surrounded by vividly colored stained-glass friezes towering more than six stories, the sun coursing through, it’s difficult not to feel the influence of a higher power. Look up at a ceiling full of stars. And look forward to the altar, behind which is one of the largest ceramic tile murals in the world"

name: A. Everett Austin House
description: This stunning Connecticut mansion is actually just a one-room-deep hoax.

name: Connecticut Museum of Culture and History
Chapel by the sea
description: How did the right arm of a 13th-century English bishop wind up in a Connecticut church?

name: Mystic Seaport Museum
description: Holding multiple historical boats and an entire 19th century village, this New England attraction is the largest maritime museum in the world.

name: Gungywamp
description: The kind of mixed-up place that drives archaeologists crazy.

name: Submarine Force Library & Museum
description: The US Navy's only submarine museum is also home to the world's first nuclear submarine.

name: Seaside Sanatorium
description: Ruins of a historic medical facility sits eerily by the water.

name: The Book Barn
description: With some 500,000 books across five buildings, this bookstore is a reader's paradise.

name: SoNo Switch Tower Museum
description: Back in the olden days, railroad traffic was controlled by a tower containing an interlocking machine with a series of mechanical levers. The SoNo Switch Tower was one of them, constructed in 1896 by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad to control switches at the junction between the New Haven Line and the Danbury Branch to move trains from one track to another, which was done by railroad employees. Open weekends, the tower features the state’s only “Armstrong” switch lever machine, so named because you needed to have a strong arm to operate it. Test your strength by throwing the levers, just as the tower operators did for nearly a century.

name: Well’s Dinosaur Haven
description: A free display of artistic lifesize dinosaur sculptures in a backyard garden.

name: American Clock & Watch Museum
description: Thousands of American timepieces on display in the former clock-making capital of the country.

name: The Carousel Museum
description: A parade of antique steeds offers a quirky ride through history.

name: Witch's Dungeon Classic Movie Museum
description: A seasonal movie monster museum featuring wax creations by a relative of one of the original Universal Studios monsters.

name: Shade Swamp
description: An abandoned Depression-era zoo hidden just off the highway.

name: PEZ Visitor Center
description: The world's largest public collection of PEZ memorabilia.

name: Hill-Stead Museum
description: NHL

name: William Kent Charitable Foundation
description: The farmhouse where a reclusive sculptor and printmaker created thousands of works.

name: Warehouse Point Library
description: A replica of fossils believed to be the first scientifically-described dinosaur bones found in North America.

name: Silver Sands State Park
description: This park is home to a massive bird sanctuary. 2.6-mile stroll on a magical ocean walkway that opens up twice daily (and also disappears twice daily).this hike is closed during the summer

name: Charles Island
description: This "thrice-cursed" island is allegedly home to Captain Kidd's lost treasure. You are not allowed on the Island from May-August due to endangered bird nesting.

name: Connecticut Trolley Museum
description: A preserved trolley track that was transformed into a museum of transportation.

name: Cogswell Memorial Fountain
description: Dr. Henry Cogswell hoped that his elaborate drinking fountains would dissuade people from drinking alcohol.

name: John Oliver "Balls of Steel" Memorial
description: After the comedian dissed a Connecticut town on his show, they named a sewage treatment plant after him.

name: HADDAM SHAD MUSEUM
description: Springtime is go time for this repurposed shack and the fish it venerates.

name: Machimoodus State Park
description: The Connecticut village named for its subterranean thunder.

name: Boothe Memorial Park
description: This eclectic homestead is home to a miniature windmill and Connecticut's last tollbooth.

name: Biology Physics Building
description: A giant ant model welcomes visitors to an exhibit about symbiotic organisms that live with army ant colonies.

name: EEB Biodiversity Education & Research Greenhouses
description: An artificial tree in the University of Connecticut greenhouses holds a collection of orchids, mosses, and other tropical epiphytic plants.

name: Ballard Institute and Museum of Puppetry
description: Celebrating an art form with a collection of puppets from all over the world.

name: Thread City Crossing
description: Public outcry led to this bridge's unique character which celebrates a giant frog battle and also sewing.

name: Best Video Film & Cultural Center
description: This Connecticut video store has a vast and varied archive that contains everything from 'Koyaanisqatsi' to 'The King's Speech.'

name: Pirelli Building
description: After decades of neglect, a brutalist icon is getting new life as an eco-friendly hotel.

name: Meriden Traffic Control Tower
description: A human attendant once directed car traffic from this structure before automated stoplights.

name: Ingalls Ice Rink
description: It looks like a whale, it's part of Yale, and it's best-known by a nickname you can probably work out for yourself.

name: The American Museum of Tort Law
description: It was founded by Ralph Nader to educate the public about an often-maligned area of law.

name: Connecticut Air & Space Center
description:
A humble air museum located in an original World War II aircraft factory. 
"oused within a former aerospace factory and across the street from Igor I. Sikorsky Memorial Airport, the Connecticut Air & Space Center has the feel of a top-secret site. The property is owned by the federal government. As a result, people under age 18 are not permitted on the site, and all visitors must stop by a security building at 550 Main St. around the corner from the museum, for a quick safety briefing before being allowed access (don’t worry, it’s safe!). Once they get “clearance,” guests are rewarded with an engrossing immersion in Connecticut’s rich aerospace history: Igor Sikorsky developed the helicopter across the street, Charles Lindbergh kept his plane nearby for a time, a line of flying saucer-like planes were briefly planned in Stratford. And, of course, Gustave Whitehead — at least according to any aviation historians in Connecticut worth their salt — beat the Wright brothers to the air. This history comes alive thanks to the showstopping restorations of many historic aircraft featured at the center. Last May, the center held a groundbreaking ceremony for the first phase of restoration on the historic Curtiss Hangar, across the street from the center."

name: Davison Art Center, Wesleyan University
description: NHL This distinctive house was built in the late 1830s in a transitional Greek-Italianate style. It now belongs to Wesleyan University.

name: The Institute Library
description: One of America's oldest private membership libraries was long one of New Haven's best kept secrets.

name: Woolsey Hall
description: Taft Chair: An extra-wide chair built to accommodate the former president's big behind.

name: Connecticut River Museum
description: This museum holds a fully-functional replica of the "Turtle," the first American submarine ever built. Dedicated to New England’s great river, the museum is housed in an 1878 Steamboat Dock building and along its surrounding docks. Guests can take an “art walk” and trace the river’s 410-mile course from northern New Hampshire to Long Island Sound; climb aboard a replica of the Turtle, the world’s first submarine used during the American Revolution; learn about the 1814 British raid on Essex; follow the historic evolution of steamboats and wooden ships; and even explore the river by sail by booking an afternoon or sunset cruise on the schooner Mary "E, from June through October"

name: Heublein Tower
description: This lovely hilltop tower was specifically built to withstand 100 MPH winds.

name: Dividend Pond And Ruins
description: Now home to hardy plants, these sand and gravel dunes once held back a massive prehistoric lake.

name: Nathan Hale Schoolhouse East Haddam
description: One of America's first spies started out as a teacher in this little red one-room schoolhouse.

name: Curioporium
description: A journey through a curious collection of oddities and wonder.

name: Tidal Marsh Trail
description: A once-booming railroad left abandoned next to the Quinnipiac River marshes now intersects with a hiking trail.  The entrance to the hiking path is behind the Target and easy to find with signs in the area for the Tidal Marsh Trail.

name: Goodspeed Opera House
description: This opera house along the banks of the Connecticut River has two Tony Awards to its credit but it’s never staged a single opera.

name: Essex Steam Train & Riverboat
description: This classic steam-powered train takes tourists on a nostalgic trip around the Connecticut River Valley.

name: Sleeping Giant Observation Tower
description: Amazing views of Long Island Sound can be seen from this mountaintop tower.

name: Remington Shot Tower
description: Connecticut's shot tower is near the end of its life.

name: Lock 12
description: This historic park site contains the last remnants of a once bustling canal system.

name: Exley Science Center
description: A small museum packed with specimens from important fossil sites and minerals from historical pegmatite quarries. TUCKED AWAY ON THE FOURTH floor of the Exley Science Center at Wesleyan University, the Joe Webb Peoples Museum is a showcase of geological and natural wonders. Though not much bigger than a large living room, the museum houses enough material for a space 10 times its size.

name: Danbury Railway Museum
description: This historic railway museum may have lost its passengers but not its love for trains.

name: The Griswold Inn
description: British troops and Prohibition couldn’t stop this spot from becoming one of the United States' oldest continuously-run taverns.

name: Mine Hill Preserve
description: The remnants of a 19th-century ironmaking complex hidden in the woods of Connecticut.

name: Harvey Cushing/John Hay Whitney Medical Library at Yale
description: A vast collection of rare books, manuscripts & extraordinary objects illustrating the history of medicine.

name: Barker Character Comic and Cartoon Museum
description: A museum dedicated to antique toys, collectibles, and nostalgia.

name: Judges Cave
description:
The cave where two British judges hid in exile after sentencing the king to death. 
"New Haveners will recognize the names Whalley, Dixwell and Goffe for three major roadways in the city. What Elm City residents and others in the state might not know is the incredible story behind the three names, a story that connects New Haven to what, at the time, were earth-shaking political developments. In 1649, during the English Civil War, some 59 British judges signed a writ of execution for Charles I (“regicide”), and three of them — Edward Whalley, John Dixwell and William Goffe — fled for the colonies. The three judges hid out on the top of West Rock in what is now called Judges Cave, a rock formation situated along the south end of Regicides Trail, a 7-mile, blue-blazed hiking trail. The cave is still there, with a plaque that tells the story with the quote: “Opposition to tyrants is obedience to God.”"

name: Yale Collection of Musical Instruments
description: A quirky assortment of musical marvels from around the world.

name: Castle Craig
description: A lone tower rises above the cliffs in a city park, offering fantastic views of the Connecticut landscape.

name: Iglesia Ni Cristo - Johnsonville Extension
description: This picturesque Victorian ghost town was once a thriving mill community.  Currently, Iglesia ni Cristo does not allow anyone on the property without permission. Since the village is on a public road, taking photos from the road should not be a problem.

name: Abbey of Regina Laudis
description: These Benedictine nuns have been making artisanal cheeses since before it was cool.

name: Hogpen Hill Farms
description: A famed data visualizer's personal sculpture garden is a landscape of modern and megalithic wonders.

name: The Glass House, National Trust for Historic Preservation
description: Home of Philip Johnson, one of the 20th century's most influential architects.

name: Hearthstone Castle
description: A castle inspired by medieval architecture is hidden in the woods of Connecticut.

name: East Rock Park
description: Panoramic views of the city of New Haven and the Long Island Sound, with a side of history.

name: Supercharged Indoor Karting and Axe Throwing
description: The world's largest indoor go-kart racetrack is hiding in Connecticut.

name: Old New-Gate Prison & Copper Mine - Seasonal
description: A former copper mine which became a truly unsuccessful prison.

name: Center Church On The Green
description: 137 graves holding New England's earliest residents.

name: The Barnum Museum
description: A museum designed by and dedicated to P.T. Barnum in the town where he is buried.

name: Dinosaur State Park
description: The ancient past meets the retro-future at these dinosaur tracks that are protected by a geodesic dome.

name: Gay City State Park
description: The ruins of an abandoned 18th-century town that is slowly being reclaimed by the forest.

name: Gillette Castle State Park
description: Quirky castle designed by the American actor best known for portraying Sherlock Holmes on stage.

name: The Cushing Center
description: An archival collection of over 2,200 case studies which includes human brain specimens and tumor specimens.

name: Abandoned Fairy Village
description:
A miniature village lies nearly forgotten in the forest by the side of a major highway.
This location does not have an address and is both very easy to get to and mildly difficult to access if you are driving there in a car. The closest place to park is Maggie McFly’s (a restaurant). To access the fairy village, find Old Waterbury Road. At the end of this road is an old access road that is now more of an overgrown trail. You cannot drive down the access road, and there are signs saying you cannot park on Old Waterbury Road or risk being towed. They don’t want people parking there to walk to the village.

While not restricted or illegal, the town doesn’t make it easy to access the area because they are worried about vandalism and misuse. You will need to walk along the service road until you see giant power lines and the highway in front of you. Once you pass under the giant power lines keep to the left going into the woods down a well-walked trail. Depending on the time of year the path is usually pretty visible. Go towards the crumbling main large human-sized hut. On the other side, you will find the cliff throne and some of the best-preserved fairy houses. There are several houses in various states of crumbling ruin scattered throughout the forest, but be careful if you stray from the trails; there is a lot of poison ivy.

name: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library
description: Yale University's home for rare works, including the mysterious Voynich Manuscript.

name: Holy Land USA Waterbury
description: A religious-themed park filled with folk art to bring biblical stories to life that fell into disrepair and now being restored.

name: Pinchot Sycamore Tree Park
description: largest tree in CT

name: CT Audubon Birdcraft Museum
description: NHL - Oldest bird sanctuary in the U.S., where Mabel Osgood Wright originated "birdscaping".

name: Roseland Cottage
description: NHL Gothic revival summer cottage visited by three U.S. presidents. Take a peek into the life of 19th-century business titan Henry Bowen and his family, who sought refuge from the heat and tumult of New York City. The 1846 Gothic Revival cottage with its lush Victorian interiors is best known for its delightful architecture and having a pink exterior — and it features the oldest surviving indoor bowling alley in the U.S.

name: New England Air Museum
description: Next to Bradley International Airport, the New England Air Museum is home to more than 100 vintage aircraft displayed in three large hangars, from early flying machines and biplanes to helicopters, fighter jets, and a B-29A Superfortress bomber. There are flight simulators and special open cockpit days when visitors can sit in the cockpit of selected aircraft. The collection extends to engines, instruments, aircraft parts, uniforms and personal memorabilia

name: Pine Knob Loop Trail Trailhead Parking
First Presbyterian Church
description: NHL - a major Modernist church design

name: Fort Shantok Archeological District
description: NHL - Mohegan settlement and home of the seventeenth century sachem Uncas.

name: Florence Griswold Museum
description: NHL - Boarding house frequented by American impressionist artists such as Henry Ward Ranger, Childe Hassam, and Willard Metcalf.

name: Slater Memorial Museum
description: The plaster cast collection is the crown jewel of the Slater Memorial Museum on the campus of Norwich Free Academy. In 1887, a fellow named Edward Robinson, head of the classical collection at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, was tapped to select sculptures to be duplicated and installed at the museum — works like the Nike of Samothrace on display at the Louvre in Paris. The Slater’s plaster cast replicas cover thousands of years of Assyrian, Egyptian, Greek, Roman and Renaissance sculptures. Paintings and artifacts from Europe are also on display, and there’s a Gallery of African Art as well.

name: Windham Textile & History Museum (the Mill Museum)
description: There’s so much to see at the Mill Museum in the former headquarters of the American Thread Co. There’s a historical society, library and archive, in addition to the museum, which preserves and interprets the history of textiles and the textile industry in Connecticut. Visitors can take in the Mill Workers’ House, Mill Manager’s Mansion, Brooke Shannon Antique Sewing Machine Room, and Peggy Church Weaving Studio, among others. And look for the special exhibit Here All Along: African Americans in Northeastern Connecticut Before the Great Migration, which explores the African American experience in northeastern Connecticut from the 1600s to 1910.

name: Connecticut Antique Machinery Museum
description: A page has been added to the CAMA website describing its newest addition — the new wing of the Connecticut Museum of Mining and Mineral Science. Called the Hall of Connecticut Geology and Paleontology, the exhibits explore the creation of the patch of earth called Connecticut, and all the upheavals that created the geology we see in the state today. The paleontology of Connecticut is another focus, though the core attraction is antique machinery and plenty of it, including industrial technology, internal combustion engines, steam engines, and machinery designed for agriculture and logging.

name: Bush-Holley House
description: The Greenwich Historical Society is home to an intriguing house museum with a dual identity; one side embodies the site’s Colonial and post-Colonial past, while the other shows off its identity as the centerpiece of the Cos Cob art colony and a bastion of American Impressionism. The most famous guest was Childe Hassam, who painted Bowl of Goldfish at the site.

name: American Radio Relay League
description: Come visit ARRL! The main adminstrative building includes a well-appointed reception area with exhibits and a membership store. Outside, visitors can navigate a self-guided tour that includes the ARRL Diamond Terrace composed of inscribed bricks placed by committed ARRL Diamond Club members, other monuments, the historic Maxim Memorial Station, W1AW, and its present-day antenna farm. For any additional questions please contact Jon Faasen, AA1EZ: 860-594-0387

name: Enders State Forest
description: short hike to Enders Falls - some consider best waterfalls in the state

name: Mattatuck Museum
description: home to the waterbury button museum

name: Saville Dam
description: "Completed in 1940 and located on the eastern branch of the Farmington River, the dam creates the 8-mile-long Barkhamsted Reservoir, which serves as the primary water source for Hartford. This is a place where you come to get away and to enjoy the quiet and the stunning views. You might even spy a soaring bald eagle. (It’s a favorite haunt of many photographers.) There are also some pleasant walking trails in the area. But if you’re planning a long stay, make sure to bring food and drinks; there are no dining options in the immediate vicinity."

name: The Shore Line Trolley Museum
description: Presenting the story of the trolley and other mass transit in a historical context, the Shoreline Trolley Museum operates the Branford Electric Railway, opened in 1900 and recognized as the oldest continuously operated suburban trolley line in the U.S. Collections include equipment, photographs, documents and artifacts, but the fun part is the ride that takes visitors past the shoreline salt marsh. During the trip, the trolley operator discusses the restored trolleys in the collection and explains how they helped shape transportation. There are also lots of fun seasonal events.

name: The Institute For American Indian Studies
description: Tucked away on 15 wooded acres, the Institute for American Indian Studies has a 16th-century Algonquian village, a fun Wigwam Escape adventure, and a museum with displays of artifacts from prehistory to the present that inform and enhance visitors’ understanding of the history and culture of Native Americans, whose story is honored and recounted through a combination of archaeology, research, exhibitions and programs.

name: Haystack Mountain Tower Parking And Trailhead
Cathedral Pines
description: one of last remaining old growth forests in region

name: Fort Trumbull State Park and Museum
Cedar Swamp
description: NNL

name: Putnam Memorial State Park
description: "Billed as “Connecticut’s Valley Forge,” Putnam Memorial State Park is the oldest state park in Connecticut. It is located on the site of the winter encampment of Gen. Israel Putnam’s Continental troops, who stayed on the grounds from December 1778 to May 1779. Guests can learn more about this Revolutionary history and the site’s archaeological surveys at the visitor center, museum and reconstructed camp buildings or by following in the footsteps of those who fought to form this country, on an interpretive trail."

name: Stewart B. McKinney National Wildlife Refuge
Denison Pequotsepos Nature Center
description: offers tours to gungywamp

name: Enders Island
description: pretty little island; used as a cathoilic retreat; in chapel, there's the arm of St Edmund

name: Pachaug State Forest
description: the Great Meadow Swamp section is a NNL

name: Blue Slope Country Museum
description: This appointment-only museum connects the land with the story of how our agricultural history played a vital role in the rural development of New England through the display of agricultural-history artifacts from the 17th through 20th centuries, including farming tools and implements, household objects, and carpentry tools. Altogether there are 4,000 artifacts in the collection. Seasonal events include square dances in the barn and tractor-driven wagon rides for the holidays.

name: Fort Griswold Battlefield State Park
description: "If you need another reason to hate Benedict Arnold, a visit here will do it. In 1781, Arnold, an American general who famously switched to the British side, led a raid on New London and Groton that resulted in the massacre of more than 80 troops at this fort across the Thames River in Groton. There is a memorial to these fallen soldiers, and guests can wander at will through the remains of the structure, which is among the best examples of a Revolutionary War fort still in existence. The Ebenezer Avery House, which sheltered the wounded after the battle, is also on the grounds. The site is part of the Thames River Heritage Park, which connects the fort with City Pier in New London and Fort Trumbull across the river by means of a water ferry running seasonally Friday, Saturday and Sunday."

name: Sculpture Walk
description: look for sculpture that commemorates the first instance of an American president pardoning a turkey.

name: 120 Huyshope Ave
description: future site of Coltsville NHP

name: Connecticut Valley Hospital
description: cemetery - not sure exactly where it is "A truly hidden Connecticut experience, the challenging and even emotionally difficult graveyard at Connecticut Valley Hospital offers a window into the troubled history of how the mentally ill were treated in Connecticut. Located at the edge of the hospital grounds, the cemetery is the final resting place of some nearly 1,700 people, buried there in numbered, unnamed graves from 1878 to 1955. In 1999, local clergy worked with the hospital and the state to get the names of those buried in the plot recovered and inscribed on a monument which now stands on Silvermine Road. The numbered graves are not easy to look at, but the cemetery is a story of lives and dignity — lost and then recovered."

name: Bigelow Hollow State Park
description: "This jewel of our park system, way up in the northeast corner and “hidden” away in the 9,000-acre Nipmuck State Forest, has a lot to keep you occupied. This time of year, you might still have some time for cross-country skiing and snowmobiling. But we think it’s during the warmer months that this park truly shines. Miles of hiking trails will keep your activity tracker on overdrive. Boating and fishing are a blast in the Mashapaug Pond, which is actually a 300-acre lake that touches the Massachusetts state line. This is one of the great places to be in the state for fall foliage, as the densely packed trees offer a fiery canvas, while the lake waters provide a beautiful mirrored surface. But also be mindful of the wondrous array of wildlife, including the occasional bobcat, moose and bear."

name: McLean Game Refuge
description: NNL

name: Nike Missile Site HA-36 control site
description: inside a state forest, the forgotten remains of a Cold War defensive installation.

name: Buttonwood Farm Ice Cream
description: only really go when the sunflowers are in bloom

name: Aerosol Techniques Factory
description: This enormous abandoned factory is now a makeshift graffiti gallery.

name: Bradley Mountain Farm
description: full moon goat hikes

name: Cunningham Tower
description: Hidden among the trees of Goshen’s Mohawk State Forest sits a little piece of history. After driving – or walking – up the winding roads of Mohawk Mountain, there’s a little trail that leads to a 20-foot tall tower. Cunningham Tower, built in 1912, was first purchased for sheep farming. Now, its inside only includes a picnic table and stone fireplace.

name: Bulls Covered Bridge
description: Take a look back in time while walking under the single-lane vehicular wooden covered bridge in Kent. While the current Bulls Bridge was constructed in 1842 from timber, the first instance of a bridge at the location over the Housatonic River was built back in 1760. It’s only one of three surviving covered bridges in the state.

name: High Rollers Luxury Lanes & Sports Lounge
The Brewery at Maple View Farm
Bunker Hill Trailhead Parking
description: Lions Head Trail - Short-and-sweet 2.1-mile hike to an awesome rocky outcropping with an even more awesome view

name: MoCA CT
description: Devoted to contemporary art, MoCA showcases an impressive mix of local and international artists, all in the service of building a deeper understanding of creative expression. A permanent exhibition by the late Westport artist Ann Weiner, When Caged Birds Sing, features eight life-size sculptures representing current women’s rights activists

name: Eric Sloane Museum
description: This museum covers a lot of ground, as it’s devoted to an artist, author and illustrator of books who also assembled an extensive collection of hand tools and Americana. The tools are displayed in a building given to the state in 1969 by Stanley Works. Sloane’s studio tells the story of his career as an artist, during which he painted landscapes inspired by the Hudson River School, and later, New England culture and Colonial life. Examples of his art are displayed in the adjacent gallery. Sloane built a pioneer cabin next to the museum, and the Kent Iron Furnace, which operated from 1826 into the 1890s, is also on the property.

name: Housatonic Museum of Art
description: Located at Housatonic Community College, this museum, spanning the history of art and on continuous display in the 300,000-square-foot building, contains works by big names such as Christo, David Hare, Leonard Baskin, Wayne Thiebaud, Ernest Briggs, Anne Arnold, Theodore Robinson, Cleve Gray, Jeff Koons, Cindy Sherman and Jenny Holzer, among others. The collection also includes African and Native American arts and artifacts.

name: William Benton Museum of Art
description: Connecticut’s official state art museum, the William Benton Museum of Art on the UConn Storrs campus has been renovated and expanded since its days as a modest operation located in a historic dining hall called The Beanery.

name: Tapping Reeve House and Law School
description: Two vice presidents, 28 U.S. senators, 101 members of the House, six cabinet members, and three U.S. Supreme Court justices were among the leaders educated at the nation’s first law school in Litchfield, opened by lawyer and judge Tapping Reeve in 1784. Visitors experience the 19th-century life of legal students, as well as students of the Litchfield Female Academy, through role-playing, hands-on areas, and interpretive exhibits. The Tapping Reeve Meadow out back, with its arbors and Adirondack chairs, is a haven where the Scarecrows in the Meadow display each fall is a smash hit.

name: Museum of Connecticut History
description: Exhibits focus on the state’s government, military and industrial history, its growth and its role in the development of the nation from the Colonial era to the present. But don’t think the museum is boring. The Colt’s Patent Firearms Manufacturing Co. collection includes the original Rampant Colt statue that sat atop the Hartford Colt factory, as well as a Colt-made Gatling gun. Fun fact: The museum has more than 50 vintage Connecticut-made toasters in its collection.

name: New England Civil War Museum
description: Housed within an original Grand Army of the Republic meeting hall — it’s the country’s oldest continuously run GAR hall — the museum has one-of-a-kind artifacts including weapons, personal items and memorabilia from the Civil War, with an emphasis on Connecticut’s contributions. With hundreds of books and periodicals in its library, the museum, founded in 1896 but not officially opened to the public as a museum until 1994, is a prime spot for research related to the Civil War and the Union Army.

name: Ruby & Calvin Fletcher African American History Museum
description: The artifacts of oppression on display here can be shocking to see in person. But they also inform, reflecting the African American experience in the U.S. from slavery and the Civil War through the civil rights movement. The “up close and personal” viewpoint of the relatively new museum (it opened in 2021) stresses teachings of tolerance, diversity, unity and educating people that there was a time when imagery played a significant role in how African Americans were perceived.

name: Prudence Crandall Museum
description: Connecticut’s official heroine isn’t a household name, but Prudence Crandall became a pioneering equal rights champion beginning in 1832 when she was the principal of the Canterbury Female Boarding School and agreed to a request from Sarah Harris, a young Black woman, to attend the school. Residents protested, Crandall closed the school but reopened the following year to serve non-white students. Things then got worse for Crandall, but litigation that resulted influenced two major U.S. Supreme Court decisions. Visitors can see period rooms, rotating exhibits, a small research library, and a new gift shop opening this season.

name: Custom House Maritime Museum - New London Maritime Society
description: Located in the historic customs house designed by noted architect Robert Mills (also responsible for the Washington Monument) and built in 1833, the Custom House Maritime Museum tells the stories of New London’s waterfront and seafaring history through exhibits, lighthouse tours, boat trips, an annual chowder festival, and displays of artifacts related to the local lighthouses and the Amistad. All of it is overseen by the New London Maritime Society. To this day, a working customs office still conducts its work here, the oldest continuously operating one in the country.

name: The Genius Museum at Nature's Art Village
description: Technology and progress are the focus at the Genius Museum at Nature’s Art Village, where guests learn how newspapers were printed in the 19th century and how a steam engine powers a boat, for example. Don’t miss the Steam Engine Room, where there’s a 2 p.m. engine startup on Saturdays and Sundays. Other exhibits include Hayday Farm, the Montville Queen steamboat, and the Oakdale Country Store.

name: National Helicopter Museum Inc
description: Located in the eastbound railroad station in Stratford, the National Helicopter Museum features a photo essay about helicopter development, a chronicle of helicopter pioneers, including Igor Sikorsky, multiple helicopter models, a T53 gas turbine engine developed in Stratford, and a computer flight simulator. The centerpiece of the museum is a full-size cockpit you can pop into.

name: Connecticut Eastern Railroad Museum
description: The Connecticut Eastern Railroad Museum, founded by members of the Connecticut Eastern Chapter of the National Railway Historical Society, is located on the site of the Columbia Junction Freight Yard, and has a collection that includes locomotives and rolling stock, vintage railroad buildings, and a six-stall roundhouse reconstructed on the original foundation. Visitors can take a guided tour of the museum, train rides are offered, and guests can even operate a replica 1850s-style pump car on a section of rail.

name: Railroad Museum of New England
description: Based in the historic Thomaston station, the Railroad Museum of New England featured in the Leonardo DiCaprio-Kate Winslet film Revolutionary Road, and has run tourist trains since the 1990s. Diesel locomotives take passengers riding in vintage coaches south alongside the Naugatuck River, or north on excursions to Torrington that cross the high rim of Thomaston Dam. Seasonal and holiday events sell out, as do special event trains on which guests enjoy local chocolate and/or bourbon.

name: Sharon Land Trust
description: A hike through bucolic Mary Moore Preserve in Sharon promises sprawling mountain views and dairy cows
